snippet: Russia’s opposition hoped to show that its ranks were unfazed by a battery of restrictions or the two-year prison sentences handed down to members of the punk rock band Pussy Riot.
abstract: Russia’s opposition movement draws tens of thousands to another large anti-Putin rally in Moscow, sending message that its ranks are undaunted by new government sanctions and the two-year prison sentences handed down to the punk-rockers of Pussy Riot; protest, like those that first jolted the Kremlin earlier in 2012, feature mockery of Pres Vladimir V Putin.

byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
byline.contributor: Andrew E. Kramer, Andrew Roth and Anna Kordunsky contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Russia’s opposition hoped to show that its ranks were unfazed by a battery of restrictions or the two-year prison sentences handed down to members of the punk rock band Pussy Riot.

headline.main: Undaunted by Arrests, the Opposition Marches Against Putin
headline.print_headline: Undaunted by Arrests, the Opposition Marches Against Putin
